channel.title: NPR Topics: Culture
channel.description: Art and entertainment commentary plus interviews, book reviews, movie reviews, music reviews, comedy, and visual art. Subscribe to podcasts and follow trends in music, painting, art, architecture, photography, and design.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: The limitations of trash TV, as seen in 'All's Fair'
item.description: Ryan Murphy's trashy melodrama further cements his parallels with Lee Daniels and Tyler Perry. But even fans of "so bad it's good" trash TV would throw their hands up in agony at Murphy's new show starring Kim Kardashian.
item.content:encoded:
All's Fair.'/>

Ryan Murphy's trashy melodrama further cements his parallels with Lee Daniels and Tyler Perry. But even fans of "so bad it's good" trash TV would throw their hands up in agony at Murphy's new show starring Kim Kardashian.

(Image credit: Ser Baffo)
item.dc:creator: Aisha Harris

item.title: 'It's Been a Minute' explores how to throw a dinner party
item.description: Government data indicates that Americans aren't throwing dinner parties as much as they used to, but there are good reasons to host them — and ways to ease the pressures of hosting.
item.content:encoded: Government data indicates that Americans aren't throwing dinner parties as much as they used to, but there are good reasons to host them — and ways to ease the pressures of hosting.
item.dc:creator: Brittany Luse

item.title: 'A Man on the Inside' goes to college, and Ted Danson aces the test
item.description: Charles (Ted Danson) went undercover in a retirement community in the first season of the hit Netflix series. In Season 2, Charles enrolls in college, and brings along a fantastic new cast.
item.content:encoded:
Charles (Ted Danson) went undercover in a retirement community in the first season of the hit Netflix series. In Season 2, Charles enrolls in college, and brings along a fantastic new cast.

(Image credit: Colleen E. Hayes)
item.dc:creator: David Bianculli

item.title: 'Nightmare Obscura' author explains how to take control of your dreams
item.description: Sleep scientist Michelle Carr has spent years researching dreaming. She explains dream engineering, including how sensory inputs like light, sound and vibration can influence the subconscious.
item.content:encoded: Sleep scientist Michelle Carr has spent years researching dreaming. She explains dream engineering, including how sensory inputs like light, sound and vibration can influence the subconscious.
item.dc:creator: Tonya Mosley

item.title: Ahead of the holidays, consumer and child advocacy groups warn against AI toys
item.description: The child advocacy nonprofit Fairplay issued an advisory on Thursday warning people against buying AI toys this holiday season. It's not the only group.
item.content:encoded:
The child advocacy nonprofit Fairplay issued an advisory on Thursday warning people against buying AI toys this holiday season. It's not the only group.

(Image credit: Elva Etienne)
item.dc:creator: Chloe Veltman

item.title: 'Wicked: For Good': This all could've been just one good movie
item.description: Part two of Jon M. Chu's splashy musical doesn't justify its own full-length movie, but it's clearly been made with love — and a deep commitment to the spirit of the material.
item.content:encoded:
Part two of Jon M. Chu's splashy musical doesn't justify its own full-length movie, but it's clearly been made with love — and a deep commitment to the spirit of the material.

(Image credit: Giles Keyte)
item.dc:creator: Aisha Harris

item.title: Here are the winners of the 2025 National Book Awards
item.description: Author Rabih Alameddine won for his novel The True True Story of Raja the Gullible (and His Mother). Other winners include a book for young people about orphans on the run in Iran during World War II.
item.content:encoded:
Author Rabih Alameddine won for his novel The True True Story of Raja the Gullible (and His Mother). Other winners include a book for young people about orphans on the run in Iran during World War II.

(Image credit: Andy Kropa)
item.dc:creator: Andrew Limbong

item.title: Malala Yousafzai said she's glad she ignored this advice from her parents
item.description: On Wild Card, well-known guests answer the kinds of questions we often think about but don't talk about. Malala Yousafzai talks about the advice from her parents she's glad she ignored.
item.content:encoded: On Wild Card, well-known guests answer the kinds of questions we often think about but don't talk about. Malala Yousafzai talks about the advice from her parents she's glad she ignored.

item.title: As a labor force, artists are 'invisible.' A new survey tries to change that
item.description: 'Struggling artists' isn't a trope, according to a new report. The survey asked more than 2,600 artists about everything from hours worked to housing.
item.content:encoded:
'Struggling artists' isn't a trope, according to a new report. The survey asked more than 2,600 artists about everything from hours worked to housing.

(Image credit: Clark Scott)
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Blair

item.title: New poetry stresses that our stories are more precious and urgent than ever
item.description: Three new collections by mid-career poets lay claim to stories of identity, suffering and hope, to a kind of collective subjectivity, to the inner life of a country in the throes of deep pain and uncertainty.
item.content:encoded: Three new collections by mid-career poets lay claim to stories of identity, suffering and hope, to a kind of collective subjectivity, to the inner life of a country in the throes of deep pain and uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Craig Morgan Teicher
